page.title: 04ECOLOGY OF ABINGTON GARDENS
page.content: Meadow Walk was a field, but now is a cul-de-sac with 14 houses. Although some large trees have been removed, some remain - chestnuts, scots pine and beech. The bats left when the trees were felled, but have now just returned. Jays, tree creepers, blue tits and a grey squirrel like to eat the beech nuts. Our winter bird table attracts the tits. We have seen a long tailed tit in our silver birch tree. A wood pigeon and collared doves sit in the scots pine. Sparrows, blue tits, blackbirds have all reared young in our garden.. The usual jack- daws and crows look for eggs and fled- glings. Swallows, swifts and house martins screech around the house. The finches feed on the seed heads in Autumn. We occasionally see a pied wagtail after a storm. We often see a wren and also there are the common
